title: Before 1 July 2020, will the Chilean government pass legislation nationalizing private pension fund assets?
preds: This forecast merely serves to confront my irrational aversion to making absolute predictions of 0% or 100% probability. I believe my typically defiant attitude of "well, anything is possible, right?" will hinder my growth as a forecaster. After studying other rationales here, and some admittedly limited research elsewhere, I'm ready to assert with certainty there is absolutely no chance of the legislation in question passing today.

https://www.bnamericas.com/en/news/chile-legislation-watch-tax-relief-bill-pension-debate "The government has opposed a proposal to allow private pension fund contributors to withdraw 10% of their savings amid the coronavirus pandemic. Cabinet members said state cash transfers, such as the so-called Covid bonus, constituted a better solution as pulling out pension savings would provide only limited support but lead to a smaller pension on retirement. The leader of pro-government party Renovación Nacional, Mario Desbordes, who supports the idea, said it would help people not covered by government aid schemes. An OECD pensions chief recently urged lawmakers to carefully analyze proposals to access pension savings, citing the impact they can have, especially if investment losses are materialized.  A law in Peru that allows savers to withdraw up to 25% of their pension savings has led to around US$4bn exiting the system. In Chile, a pension reform bill is in congress." @ManuPV
Highly unlikely due to the controversies and lack of majority support

It looks like reform may be on horizon with the new constitutional amendment introduced. What makes it unlikely is the timeframe, and the nature of the debate. The next election cycle I think some kind of reform is closer to 40% likely with some form
Of nationalization 25% likely.

https://www.bnamericas.com/en/news/oecd-pension-chief-says-reforms-must-continue-urges-crisis-policy-caution "Chile’s government already has a bill in congress, . . .
Chile – which has a defined-contribution, or private scheme, and a solidarity pillar – is among those that have embarked along the reform path to boost pension size, a hot topic in the country.  . . . Chile’s government already has a bill in congress, which establishes a complementary public scheme and also gets employers to start contributing to the savings pots of workers.  “The process should not stop,” said Pablo Antolin, principal economist at the private pension unit of the OECD financial affairs division. Citing demographic and economic pressures, he said workers needed to save more and for longer, and that fee and commission structures needed to be analyzed. However, citing the example of Chile, he said lawmakers may need to reconsider how any new rules that involve introducing employer contributions are implemented, suggesting they could be phased in first in sectors of the economy that are more resilient to the COVID-19 fallout. Chile’s labor minister, María José Zaldívar, recently said the government was open to changing how employer contributions are phased in, local paper Diario Financiero reported.  . . .  Meanwhile, Antolin [ principal economist at the private pension unit of the OECD financial affairs division] .. .  urged authorities to carefully consider the possible negative long-term consequences of pension freedom and contribution holiday measures. Such policies could reduce the size of the pension that workers receive on retirement. Antolin said countries with the requisite fiscal clout should explore alternatives such as subsidies. Easing investment rules – such as Chile’s move to allow funds to invest more in alternative assets – is another option as long as the risks are fully analyzed, he said. Pulling out funds now, following the recent plunge in financial asset value, could compound the impact on savers. “Access to retirement savings has to be the last resort and must be based on exceptional and personal circumstances,” Antolin said in a presentation. “Accessing savings will lead to a materialization of losses, fund liquidity and investment problems and, above all, a potential pension sufficiency problem on retirement.” Opposition lawmakers in Chile have said members of private pension funds should be allowed access to some of their savings to help them weather the crisis.  . . . In Chile, at the end of March, AUM stood at US$171bn, down from US$215bn at the end of 2019, which was a bumper year in terms of fund performance.

Read articles in Spanish in today's editions of Santiago daily, La Tercera, and you might get the sense that by the date mentioned, this aint gonna happen.
https://www.latercera.com/pulso/noticia/no-podemos-descuidar-las-pensiones-del-futuro-ministra-zaldivar-reacciona-propuesta-mesa-tecnica-la-oposicion/972886/

The key phrases in this question is "nationalizing private pension fund assets" and "compelling the divestiture or transfer of privately held pension funds to a public entity or the state".  These are high bars.  They involved not only a complete change of direction of Chile's pension system from private control to government control.  It is difficult to see this happen in a center-right government.   While there are talks of having "employers to pick up the tab for an additional 4 percent contribution to each of their workers´ pension funds, to be phased in and managed by an administrator of the employee´s choosing" (1), they do not constitute nationalization. A more drastic change could happen if there is a change in the government controlled by left leaning parties.  But presidential and parliamentary elections won't be held until November 21, 2021.  Therefore there is little chance that nationalization of pension funds by July 1 2020 or 2021. (1) https://www.reuters.com/article/us-chile-economy/chiles-pinera-presents-pension-reform-plan-in-bid-to-boost-payouts-idUSKCN1N304H
It will eventually happen if the elections continue with the present trend but too early to take place in July 2020

Before 1 July 2020, will the Chilean government pass legislation nationalizing private pension fund assets?
Hattip @Tuzlarob and @Anneinak and @cafebedouin for their insights. It would seem to be too little time to move this ship.
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-chile-protests/chiles-president-sends-congress-plan-to-slash-health-care-costs-after-protests-idUSKBN1Z40QN President Pinera has less radical plan

12 percent of the population supports the govt at this time. The unhappy pensioners aren't getting the money the govt encouraged them to privatize and withdraw from public system 1990s...based on the pension they should be getting 1600 a month promised off a 2k a month working salary.  Instead the first collector's are getting about 400 a month.  As more retire, the masses will get more disgruntled.  Forcing govt to cover.
No real knowledge here - just assuming this is unlikely, but no so unlikely that the question wouldn't be asked.
@cafebedouin is persuasive in noting Chile needs a new constitution first https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/932918
Based on analysis by @cafebedouin, I don't believe that there is enough time for the Chilean government to get this done.
Manifestations are clearly of the color revolution type, and those purpott the agenda of Banks.

Pension fund nationalization has happened before in various countries - Argentina, Hungary, Ireland, Poland, Portugal, France etc. It is considered as undesirable universally and has been unpopular in most countries where it was introduced. Politicians and state are not trusted to manage the funds profitably and are cynically expected to siphon off funds out of it to fill their pockets.  Considering that Chilean pension funds are managed profitably and that the Chilean government is not beset with deficit concerns which cannot be addressed by other fiscal means, I consider it unlikely that the current private pension fund assets would be nationalized. This could result in further uproar considering the poor pension payouts already in place.

I agree with @cafebedouin https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/932918 It seems to me that pension reform is one of the icebergs on which ships of state frequently flounder.  (Another is a dramatic reduction in government subsidies of a basic commodity,)  It's one of those things that everyone wants--in theory--but only if it improves their benefits, and that the rich and powerful oppose, so find ways to make it appear like reform has been enacted when it has not.

It is likely not a matter of whether or not it will happen, it is a matter of when.  The government's attempts to address the economic issues have been unsuccessful and now will result in an April 2020 referendum on the development of a new constitution.  If the population votes to keep the current constitution, there will be less than two months to develop the law or amendment necessary to nationalize the pensions.  If the population votes for a new constitution, the process of framing and choosing delegates alone will certainly take more than two months.

No, they won't. They are starting a process to completely rewrite their constitution. First, it needs to be put to a vote. They need to decide on process. They need to select people to write it. They need to actually write it. Then, whatever Constitution has to be voted and on approved. This will take until at least July 2021 and likely longer. While this is going on, will they make any moves to refactor the pension system? No, they won't. For one, support is flagging among the adult population. Two, there is no clear path about what to do regarding pensions. It's a topic that has deep divisions within society that goes back to questions about dictatorships, corruption, benefits and other factors. They'll probably try to handle this as part of the Constitutional rewrite process, and there will be many opportunities for this to be shifted to the wayside by people's whose lunch it will impact. There's zero chance this happens in this time frame. As a base rate, it's been reformed twice since 1926, that's an annual rate of just over 2%.  "It took more than twenty meetings in the National Congress, the last of which ran into the early morning hours of November 15th, for ten political parties, from the right-wing coalition Chile Vamos to the left-leaning Frente Amplio, to reach an agreement about the constitution. The parties announced that the government will hold a plebiscite in April of next year, in which Chileans will be asked whether they want a new constitution. Those who do will also be able to indicate whether they think it should be written by a constitutional convention made up of members of Congress and private citizens chosen in local elections or one of elected citizens alone. If approved, citizens will then elect the members of the convention in October, which will have nine to twelve months to draft the new text. Once finished, Chileans will vote again, to approve or reject the constitution."[1] "This privatized retirement system is one of obligatory savings; it is not voluntary. It was created in the 1980s and was implemented by force. The system currently has over 10 million participants. All workers must participate. It was sold to the Chilean public on the claim that people would retire with 75 percent of their most recent salaries. A lie...In fact, the pensions that people receive are truly miserable. An average pension for a man is $492 per month. For women, on average, $295 per month. It’s lunacy!"[2]  "Protesters say they have no plans to stop and like Catalina Santana, many are high-schoolers, who have shown up at protest after protest even as adults and university-age students stopped attending."[3] "The divisions, both within the Commission and in wider society, hampered the ability of the Commission to make strong, fully (or largely) worked-out recommendations. Thus the specific proposals show a direction of travel, but more work is needed on many of the details; and there is no agreement about
the need, or lack of need, for basic structural change."[4] [1] https://www.newyorker.com/news/daily-comment/as-protests-rock-chile-the-people-consider-rewriting-pinochets-constitution
[2] https://www.thenation.com/article/chile-protests-inequality-pinochet/
[3] https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/students-driving-protests-demanding-change-chile-67574609
[4] https://www.aeaweb.org/conference/2017/preliminary/1440#
